evidence.pdf_reference: porous ZnO nanoplates.The main photoreduction product over all the obtained ZnO samples is CO.Blank experiments are also conducted (i.e., without CO2, illumination or photocatalysts), no any photoreduction products like CH4 or CO can be observed, confirming that the observed CO is indeed from CO2 photoreduction.Fig. 4 shows the CO production as a function of illumination time.Obviously, the amount of CO increases as the illumination time prolongs for all the samples.The production yield of CO is 3.8, 3.1

curves were measured on a CHI 660D electrochemical station (Shanghai Chenhua, China).The 0.35 M Na2SO4 was used as the electrolyte.A standard three-electrode system was used for the photoelectrochemical tests, i.e., the electrode coated by the obtained sample was used as the working electrode, a platinum plate as the counter electrode, and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode.The photocurrent was measured at a bias voltage of 0.6 V with light on and off every 15 seconds.The

pure CO2 was first bubbled into 100 mL of solution containing 0.25 M Na2SO3 and 1 M NaOH for at least 30 min.Then 30 mg of ZnO powder was suspended in the above solution under sonication for 30 min, followed by being bubbled with pure compressed CO2 ( 99.999) for another 30 min in the dark to reach the balance of CO2 adsorption-desorption before illumination.The products were collected every 30 min and analyzed online by gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890A) equipped with flame ionization detector (FID) and

respectively.Therefore, the difference in the alignment of energy levels among all the obtained ZnO samples (specifically, the potential of CB and flat band, as well as Eg) is very small.Accordingly, another factor, here the defects in the nanocatalysts as discussed below, is suggested to play a major role in the observed different photoreduction activity. yield of CO is 3.8, 3.1 and 2.5 molg for the catalyst of ZnO-600, ZnO-650 and ZnO-700, respectively.Thus, the ZnO-600 sample has the highest activity for CO2 photoreduction, followed by ZnO-650, and ZnO-700 shows the lowest activity.Transient photocurrent response results further confirm such a sequence in activity, i.e., the ZnO-600 sample has the largest photocurrent density under the same measurement conditions, followed by ZnO-650, and ZnO-700 is the lowest (Fig. 4b).Moreover, the photocurrent
